sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: This chapter describes the overall behavior of the user interface. Description of the various component parts—the menu bar, panes and various diagrams— is in separate chapters.

sect1.title: Overview of the Window

textobject.para: A display of the &argouml; window, showing at the top the menu bar, in the main area four sub-windows and at the bottom a status bar. The four sub-windows are arranged two by two, and named, clockwise from top left as: navigator pane, editing pane, details pane and to-do pane. at the top of the editing pane is a horizontal tool bar.

sect1.para: At the top of screen is a menu bar described in . The bulk of the window comprises four sub-windows or panes. Clockwise from top left these are the navigator pane (see ), editing pane (see ), details pane (see ) and to-do pane (see ). At the top of the editing pane is a tool bar. An overview of the panes is given in . Finally at the bottom of the window is a status bar described in .

sect1.title: General Mouse Behavior in &argouml;
sect1.para: Mouse behaviour that is specific to the various panes of &argouml; (see ) or the menu bar, is discussed in the chapters covering those panes and the menu bar. In this section we cover behaviour that is general across all of &argouml;.
In a number of places in &argouml; text may be directly edited (for example the constraint editor—see ). The behaviour of the mouse when handling text is discussed in the sections that follow.

sect2.title: Mouse Button Terminology
sect2.para: &argouml; assumes a two button mouse. We will refer to the buttons as &button1; and &button2;. &Button1; is the leftmost button on a right-handed mouse, and sometimes referred to as the select button. &Button2; is the rightmost button on a right-handed mouse, and is sometimes referred to as the adjust button.

A single depress and release of a mouse button whilst the mouse is still is referred to as a click. Two clicks in quick succession is referred to as a double click. Moving the mouse while holding a button down is referred to as button motion with the starting point being at button down and the end point at button up.

sect2.title: &Button1; Click
sect2.para: This action is generally used to select an item for subsequent operations. If the item is an artifact in the navigation pane or the editing pane it will be highlighted.

sect3.title: General Behaviour When Editing Text
sect3.para: Here &button1; is used to select the point within the text at which operations (text entry and deletion) will take place.

sect2.title: &Button1; Double Click
sect2.para: The behaviour of &button1; double click varies betweens panes and is discussed in their chapters.

sect3.title: General Behaviour When Editing Text
sect3.para: Here &button1; double click is used to select a complete word, or other syntactic unit within the text. Subsequent operations (text entry and deletion) will replace the selected text.

sect3.title: General Behaviour When Editing Text
sect3.para: Here &button1; motion is used to select a range of text. Subsequent operations (text entry and deletion) will replace the selected text.

sect3.title: Within Lists
sect3.para: This behavior applies where there is a list of things that may be selected. This includes various dialog boxes, and the to-do pane, where there is a list of to-do items to be selected.
Similarly the CONTROL key with &button1; is used to add individual items to the current selection. Where Ctrl-&button1; is used on an item already selected, that item is removed from the selection.

caution.para: Users of Microsoft Windows will be familiar with the use SHIFT and CONTROL together to add sub-lists to an existing selection. &argouml; does not support this. SHIFT-CONTROL will behave as CONTROL.

sect3.title: General Behaviour When Editing Text
sect3.para: In a number of places in &argouml; text may be directly edited (for example the constraint editor—see ). Here SHIFT &button1; is used to select a range of text from the previously selected point. Subsequent operations (text entry and deletion) will replace the selected text.

sect2.title: &Button2; Actions
sect2.para: &Button2; actions are all dependent on the pane or menu bar, and discussed in their various chapters.

sect1.title: General Information About Panes
sect1.para: The four sub-windows of the main &argouml; window are called panes. Clockwise from top left these are the navigator pane (see ), editing pane (see ), details pane (see ) and to-do pane (see ). At the top the editing pane is a tool bar.

sect2.title: Re-sizing Panes
sect2.para: You can re-size panes by dragging on the divider bars between them. The mouse cursor changes to a vertical or horizontal bar with an arrow at right-angles when over the divider bars.

sect2.title: Looking at Different Diagrams Simultaneously
sect2.para: &argouml; provides the ability to spawn copies of key windows. This is possible for the editing pane and for the tabs of the details pane. These can then be manipulated as separate windows and placed as desired on the screen.
This is achieved through use of &button1; double click as described in sections and .

note.para: There is no equivalent function for the navigation or to-do panes.

sect2.title: Reducing the Number of Panes Visible
sect2.para: This function is not implemented directly. However you can spawn a pane (see ) and maximize this to be the whole window, which achieves the same thing.

sect1.title: The status bar
sect1.para: The status bar is at the very bottom of the &argouml; window and is used to display short advisory messages. In general such messages are self explanatory. It is also used for debugging messages for the system in development—these messages can be ignored.
